title: The effects of underwater pressure on the body - Neosha S Kashef

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the bodily damage caused by rapid changes in pressure experienced by fish when they are reeled up to the surface?

options.label: A
options.text: Decompression sickness

options.label: B
options.text: Barotrauma

options.label: C
options.text: Exophthalmia

options.label: D
options.text: Corneal emphysemas

multiple-choice.question: According to Boyle's gas law, what happens to the volume of a gas when it experiences an increase in pressure?

options.label: A
options.text: It expands

options.label: B
options.text: It remains the same

options.label: C
options.text: It compresses

options.label: D
options.text: It disappears

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the condition where the air in a fish's swim bladder expands rapidly, causing its stomach to be pushed out of its mouth and its eyes to be pushed out of their sockets?

options.label: A
options.text: Decompression sickness

options.label: B
options.text: Exophthalmia

options.label: C
options.text: Corneal emphysemas

options.label: D
options.text: Barotrauma

multiple-choice.question: According to Henry's law, what happens to the amount of a gas that dissolves in a liquid when its partial pressure increases?

options.label: A
options.text: It decreases

options.label: B
options.text: It remains the same

options.label: C
options.text: It increases

options.label: D
options.text: It disappears

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the condition where a diver experiences pain and potentially death due to the formation of microbubbles in their tissues, blood, and joints?

options.label: A
options.text: Decompression sickness

options.label: B
options.text: Barotrauma

options.label: C
options.text: Exophthalmia

options.label: D
options.text: Corneal emphysemas

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of decompression stops for a diver?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase the amount of gas in their tissues

options.label: B
options.text: To decrease the amount of gas in their tissues

options.label: C
options.text: To remain the same

options.label: D
options.text: To cause pain and potentially death

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the device that can be used to lower a fish back into the sea at the right depth, allowing it to recompress and recover from barotrauma?

options.label: A
options.text: Descending device

options.label: B
options.text: Ascending device

options.label: C
options.text: Decompression device

options.label: D
options.text: Recompression device

multiple-choice.question: What happens to a fish's body when it experiences barotrauma?

options.label: A
options.text: It remains the same

options.label: B
options.text: It inflates and its eyes and stomach are pushed out of their sockets

options.label: C
options.text: It deflates and its eyes and stomach return to their normal positions

options.label: D
options.text: It disappears

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the common myth about treating a fish with barotrauma?

options.label: A
options.text: That piercing its stomach with a needle will let air escape, allowing the fish to swim back down on its own

options.label: B
options.text: That the fish will recover on its own if left in the sea

options.label: C
options.text: That the fish will never recover from barotrauma

options.label: D
options.text: That the fish will not experience any pain from barotrauma

multiple-choice.question: What is the long-term outcome for a fish that is treated properly for barotrauma using a descending device?

options.label: A
options.text: It will die from decompression sickness

options.label: B
options.text: It will experience long-term pain and suffering

options.label: C
options.text: It will recover and live to see another day

options.label: D
options.text: It will never be able to swim or reproduce again

title: What did democracy really mean in Athens? - Melissa Schwartzberg

multiple-choice.question: **Knowledge**: What is the term for the process of randomized selection used in ancient Athens to fill certain government positions?

options.label: A
options.text: Election

options.label: B
options.text: Aristocracy

options.label: C
options.text: Democracy

options.label: D
options.text: Sortition

multiple-choice.question: **Comprehension**: Describe the Athenian system of governance, including the role of the Boule and the principle of ho boulomenos.

options.label: A
options.text: The Boule was a governing council chosen by lottery, and ho boulomenos allowed any citizen to participate in the ecclesia, proposing laws, or bringing public lawsuits.

options.label: B
options.text: The Boule was a governing council appointed by the nobles, and ho boulomenos was a system of aristocratic rule.

options.label: C
options.text: The Boule was a governing council elected by the citizens, and ho boulomenos limited participation to a select few.

options.label: D
options.text: The Boule was a governing council chosen by lottery, and ho boulomenos was a system of direct democracy.

multiple-choice.question: **Application**: If a modern democracy were to adopt a system of election by lottery, what potential benefits could it bring to government?

options.label: A
options.text: A more centralized and authoritarian government

options.label: B
options.text: A more corrupt and incompetent government

options.label: C
options.text: A more efficient and effective government

options.label: D
options.text: A more diverse and representative group of legislatures

multiple-choice.question: **Analysis**: What are some of the limitations of the Athenian system of governance, and how do they relate to the modern concept of democracy?

options.label: A
options.text: The Athenian system excluded women, slaves, and foreigners from full citizenship, and modern democracies have expanded voting rights to include these groups.

options.label: B
options.text: The Athenian system was too focused on the needs of the many, and modern democracies have a more nuanced approach to governance.

options.label: C
options.text: The Athenian system was too decentralized, and modern democracies have a more centralized approach to governance.

options.label: D
options.text: The Athenian system was too corrupt, and modern democracies have a more transparent approach to governance.

multiple-choice.question: **Synthesis**: How might the principles of sortition and direct democracy be combined to create a more effective and representative system of governance?

options.label: A
options.text: By using sortition to select a representative sample of citizens to participate in a deliberative poll, and then using direct democracy to make decisions based on the outcomes of the poll.

options.label: B
options.text: By using direct democracy to make decisions on all issues, without any representation or deliberation.

options.label: C
options.text: By using sortition to select a governing council to make decisions on behalf of the citizens, and then using direct democracy to hold the council accountable.

options.label: D
options.text: By using a combination of sortition and direct democracy, with citizens participating in both a representative sample and a deliberative poll.

multiple-choice.question: **Evaluation**: What are some of the potential drawbacks of relying on sortition and direct democracy, and how might they be mitigated?**

options.label: A
options.text: The lack of expertise and experience among citizens may lead to poor decision-making, but this could be mitigated by providing citizens with education and training.

options.label: B
options.text: The potential for tyranny of the majority may lead to the exclusion of minority groups, but this could be mitigated by ensuring that all citizens have an equal voice and that decisions are made through a deliberative process.

options.label: C
options.text: The potential for corruption and inefficiency may lead to a lack of trust in the system, but this could be mitigated by implementing robust checks and balances and ensuring that citizens have access to information and resources.

options.label: D
options.text: The potential for anarchy and chaos may lead to a breakdown in social order, but this could be mitigated by establishing clear rules and procedures and ensuring that citizens have a sense of community and shared responsibility.

multiple-choice.question: **Knowledge**: What is the term for the system of governance in which citizens elect representatives to make decisions on their behalf?

options.label: A
options.text: Representative democracy

options.label: B
options.text: Oligarchy

options.label: C
options.text: Democracy

options.label: D
options.text: Aristocracy

multiple-choice.question: **Comprehension**: Describe the differences between the Athenian system of governance and modern representative democracies.

options.label: A
options.text: The Athenian system was a direct democracy in which citizens participated directly in decision-making, while modern representative democracies have a more indirect system in which citizens elect representatives to make decisions on their behalf.

options.label: B
options.text: The Athenian system was a representative democracy in which citizens elected representatives to make decisions on their behalf, while modern representative democracies have a more direct system in which citizens participate directly in decision-making.

options.label: C
options.text: The Athenian system was a monarchy in which a single ruler made decisions on behalf of the citizens, while modern representative democracies have a more complex system in which power is distributed among different branches of government.

options.label: D
options.text: The Athenian system was an oligarchy in which a small group of elites made decisions on behalf of the citizens, while modern representative democracies have a more inclusive system in which citizens have a greater say in decision-making.

multiple-choice.question: **Application**: How might the principles of sortition and direct democracy be applied in a modern context, such as in a citizens' assembly or a deliberative poll?

options.label: A
options.text: By using direct democracy to make decisions on all issues, without any representation or deliberation.

options.label: B
options.text: By using sortition to select a governing council to make decisions on behalf of the citizens, and then using direct democracy to hold the council accountable.

options.label: C
options.text: By using a combination of sortition and direct democracy, with citizens participating in both a representative sample and a deliberative poll.

multiple-choice.question: **Evaluation**: What are some of the potential benefits and drawbacks of using sortition and direct democracy in a modern context, and how might they be weighed against one another?

options.label: A
options.text: The potential benefits of using sortition and direct democracy include greater citizen engagement and participation, but the potential drawbacks include the risk of poor decision-making and the potential for tyranny of the majority.

options.label: B
options.text: The potential benefits of using sortition and direct democracy include greater efficiency and effectiveness, but the potential drawbacks include the risk of corruption and the potential for anarchy.

options.label: C
options.text: The potential benefits of using sortition and direct democracy include greater transparency and accountability, but the potential drawbacks include the risk of gridlock and the potential for polarization.

options.label: D
options.text: The potential benefits of using sortition and direct democracy include greater inclusivity and representation, but the potential drawbacks include the risk of exclusion and the potential for manipulation.

title: Where did Earth’s water come from? - Zachary Metz

options.label: B
options.text: Photosynthesis

options.label: C
options.text: Fission

options.label: D
options.text: Fusion

options.label: A
options.text: They suspected it came from ice-bearing comets and asteroids, but recent research suggests it may have been present on Earth from the start.

options.label: B
options.text: They suspected it came from volcanic activity, but recent research suggests it may have been brought by comets and asteroids.

options.label: C
options.text: They suspected it came from the oceans and rivers, but recent research suggests it may have been present on Earth from the start.

options.label: D
options.text: They suspected it came from the atmosphere, but recent research suggests it may have been brought by comets and asteroids.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: It would mean that life may have formed on Venus instead of Earth.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Photosynthesis

options.label: C
options.text: Respiration

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: Nucleosynthesis

options.label: B
options.text: Photosynthesis

options.label: C
options.text: Fission

options.label: D
options.text: Fusion

options.label: A
options.text: They brought water to the Earth and formed the oceans.

options.label: B
options.text: They did not bring water to the Earth and did not form the oceans.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It came from the atmosphere.

options.label: C
options.text: It came from the Earth's core.

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B

title: Why it’s so hard to cure HIV/AIDS - Janet Iwasa

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary method of HIV transmission?

options.label: A
options.text: Airborne transmission

options.label: B
options.text: Unprotected sex and contaminated needles

options.label: C
options.text: Casual contact

options.label: D
options.text: Waterborne transmission

options.label: A
options.text: B cells

options.label: B
options.text: Helper T cells

options.label: C
options.text: Macrophages

options.label: D
options.text: Neutrophils

options.label: B
options.text: HIV latency

options.label: C
options.text: HIV progression

options.label: D
options.text: HIV dormancy

multiple-choice.question: How do antiretroviral drugs work to manage HIV levels in the body?

options.label: A
options.text: By killing HIV-infected cells

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: By maturing or assembling HIV

options.label: D
options.text: By suppressing the immune system

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult to cure HIV, even with current treatments?

options.label: A
options.text: Because HIV is a highly contagious virus

options.label: B
options.text: Because HIV can hide out in the DNA of healthy T cells

options.label: C
options.text: Because HIV can be transmitted through casual contact

options.label: D
options.text: Because HIV is a rare virus

options.label: A
options.text: Limited access to antiretroviral therapies

options.label: B
options.text: High cost of antiretroviral therapies

options.label: C
options.text: Limited availability of HIV testing

options.label: D
options.text: Limited understanding of HIV transmission

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential approach to developing a true cure for HIV?

options.label: A
options.text: Using a drug to activate all cells harboring the HIV genetic information

options.label: B
options.text: Using genetic tools to cut the HIV DNA out of cells genomes altogether

options.label: C
options.text: Using antiretroviral therapies to manage HIV levels

options.label: D
options.text: Using vaccines to prevent HIV transmission

multiple-choice.question: Why is a cure for HIV still a topic of research, despite the availability of effective treatments?

options.label: A
options.text: Because HIV is a rare virus

options.label: B
options.text: Because HIV is a highly contagious virus

options.label: C
options.text: Because HIV can hide out in the DNA of healthy T cells

options.label: D
options.text: Because HIV still claims thousands of lives per year

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the 2008 case of a man being cured of HIV?

options.label: A
options.text: It marked the beginning of HIV research

options.label: B
options.text: It showed that HIV can be transmitted through casual contact

options.label: C
options.text: It demonstrated that a cure for HIV is possible

options.label: D
options.text: It highlighted the need for HIV testing

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential outcome of ongoing research into a cure for HIV?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: An increase in the number of people living with HIV

options.label: C
options.text: A cure for HIV that is accessible to everyone

options.label: D
options.text: A vaccine to prevent HIV transmission

title: How does the thyroid manage your metabolism? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the thyroid gland in the body?

options.label: A
options.text: To filter waste products from the blood

options.label: B
options.text: To produce hormones that regulate metabolism

options.label: C
options.text: To produce antibodies that fight infection

options.label: D
options.text: To store nutrients for energy

multiple-choice.question: Which two hormones produced by the thyroid gland are responsible for regulating metabolism?

options.label: A
options.text: Insulin and glucagon

options.label: B
options.text: Thyroxine and triiodothyronine (T3 and T4)

options.label: C
options.text: Adrenaline and noradrenaline

options.label: D
options.text: Growth hormone and prolactin

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the pituitary gland in relation to the thyroid gland?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce hormones that inhibit the thyroid gland

options.label: B
options.text: To produce hormones that stimulate the thyroid gland

options.label: C
options.text: To oversee the thyroid gland's tasks and ensure it produces the correct amount of hormones

multiple-choice.question: What happens when the thyroid gland produces too many hormones?

options.label: A
options.text: The body's cells become underactive and metabolism slows

options.label: B
options.text: The body's cells become overactive and metabolism increases

options.label: C
options.text: The body's cells remain unchanged and metabolism remains steady

options.label: D
options.text: The body's cells become dormant and metabolism ceases

options.label: C
options.text: Fatigue, muscle weakness, hair loss

options.label: D
options.text: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Through meditation and relaxation techniques

options.label: D
options.text: Through avoidance of certain environmental toxins

multiple-choice.question: What are the consequences of the thyroid gland becoming "deaf" to the pituitary gland's guiding commands?

options.label: B
options.text: The thyroid gland becomes underactive and produces too few hormones

options.label: C
options.text: The thyroid gland remains unchanged and continues to function normally

options.label: D
options.text: The thyroid gland becomes dormant and ceases to function

options.label: B
options.text: The thyroid gland regulates the body's metabolic rate, but has no significant impact on it

options.label: C
options.text: The thyroid gland regulates the body's metabolic rate and affects it significantly

options.label: D
options.text: The thyroid gland is responsible for producing the body's metabolic rate

multiple-choice.question: What are some potential causes of the thyroid gland becoming "deaf" to the pituitary gland's guiding commands?

options.label: B
options.text: Poor diet, lack of exercise, and stress

options.label: C
options.text: Genetics, family history, and environmental toxins

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: The law of conservation of mass - Todd Ramsey

multiple-choice.question: What is the law of conservation of mass, as described in the transcript?

options.text: The law states that mass can be created or destroyed within an isolated system.

options.text: The law states that mass, a.k.a. matter and energy, can neither be created nor destroyed within an isolated system.

options.text: It has no significance at all

title: Why the Arctic is climate change's canary in the coal mine - William Chapman

multiple-choice.question: What is the Arctic often referred to as in terms of climate change?

options.label: A
options.text: The Earth's core

options.label: B
options.text: The canary in the coal mine

options.label: C
options.text: The polar bear's habitat

options.label: D
options.text: The ice cap

multiple-choice.question: What type of climate feedback involves reflectivity in the Arctic, where white surfaces reflect the sun's energy back into space, while darker surfaces absorb more incoming sunlight?

options.label: A
options.text: Absorption

options.label: B
options.text: Reflectivity

options.label: C
options.text: Conduction

options.label: D
options.text: Radiation

multiple-choice.question: What happens when the Arctic warms and some of the snow and ice melts, exposing the ground and ocean underneath?

options.label: A
options.text: The increased heat absorbed by these surfaces causes even more melting

options.label: B
options.text: The ground and ocean underneath get colder

options.label: C
options.text: The ground and ocean underneath get warmer

options.label: D
options.text: The Arctic gets colder

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of Arctic sea ice in the ocean's surface?

options.label: A
options.text: It prevents heat from escaping

options.label: B
options.text: It acts as a buffer between the arctic air and the warmer water underneath

options.label: C
options.text: It absorbs more sunlight

options.label: D
options.text: It reflects more sunlight

multiple-choice.question: What type of feedback loop is formed when melting ice releases moisture into the atmosphere, which increases the amount and thickness of clouds, cooling the atmosphere by blocking more sunlight?

options.label: A
options.text: Positive feedback loop

options.label: B
options.text: Negative feedback loop

options.label: C
options.text: Both positive and negative feedback loops

options.label: D
options.text: No feedback loop

multiple-choice.question: What is the consequence of the recently increased impact of positive feedbacks on the planet?

options.label: A
options.text: The planet warms at a slower rate

options.label: B
options.text: The planet cools at a faster rate

options.label: C
options.text: The planet warms at a faster rate, especially in the middle latitudes

options.label: D
options.text: The planet remains stable

multiple-choice.question: How may shifts in weather patterns affect the middle latitudes, where most of the world's population lives?

options.label: A
options.text: They will lead to more stable and predictable weather patterns

options.label: B
options.text: They will lead to less extreme and persistent weather patterns

options.label: C
options.text: They will lead to longer-lasting and more extreme weather patterns, such as cold snaps, heat waves, droughts, and floods

options.label: D
options.text: They will have no effect on the middle latitudes

multiple-choice.question: What is the warning that climate scientists often give about the Arctic's feedback loops?

options.label: A
options.text: What happens in the Arctic stays in the Arctic

options.label: B
options.text: The Arctic is not a key indicator of climate change

options.label: C
options.text: What happens in the Arctic doesn't always stay in the Arctic

options.label: D
options.text: The Arctic is not vulnerable to climate change

multiple-choice.question: What type of feedback loop encourages stability by pushing a system towards equilibrium?

options.label: A
options.text: Positive feedback loop

options.label: B
options.text: Negative feedback loop

options.label: C
options.text: Both positive and negative feedback loops

options.label: D
options.text: No feedback loop

multiple-choice.question: What is the main consequence of the Arctic's feedback loops on the planet?

options.label: A
options.text: The planet will cool at a faster rate

options.label: B
options.text: The planet will remain stable

options.label: C
options.text: The planet will warm at a faster rate, especially in the middle latitudes

options.label: D
options.text: The planet will experience more extreme weather patterns

title: McDonald's Cup Sizes Around The World

options.text: Troposphere

options.text: Mesosphere

options.label: D
options.text: Thermosphere

What is the primary function of the ozone layer in the Stratosphere?

options.label: B
options.text: To protect the Earth from harmful ultraviolet radiation

options.label: C
options.text: To influence the Earth's rotation

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: Mesosphere

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: To protect the Earth from harmful ultraviolet radiation

options.label: C
options.text: To influence the Earth's rotation

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of atmospheric gases escaping into space in the Exosphere?

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: Gaius Cassius Longinus and Marcus Junius Brutus

options.label: C
options.text: Mark Antony

options.label: D
options.text: Pompey the Great

options.label: B
options.text: Dictator

options.label: C
options.text: Imperator

options.label: D
options.text: Tribune

options.text: July

options.text: 30 times

options.text: Marcus Junius Brutus

options.label: C
options.text: Mark Antony

options.label: B
options.text: The rise of a new dynasty

options.label: C
options.text: The end of the Roman Republic and the concentration of power under the office of Emperor

options.text: The end of the Roman Empire

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: He was becoming too popular among the Roman public

options.label: C
options.text: He was gaining too much power and threatened the Roman Republic

options.label: D
options.text: He was becoming too wealthy and threatened the Roman economy

options.label: B
options.text: He was hesitant to join the conspiracy

options.label: C
options.text: He was not a member of the conspiracy

options.text: He was a key member of the conspiracy who had a personal reservations about the assassination

options.label: A
options.text: The rise of a new dynasty

options.label: B
options.text: The establishment of a new constitution

options.label: C
options.text: The end of the Roman Empire

options.label: D
options.text: The end of the Roman Republic and the concentration of power under the office of Emperor

options.label: B

title: How do the lungs work? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the respiratory system in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: To regulate body temperature

options.label: B
options.text: To transport oxygen to the body's cells and clear carbon dioxide from the system

options.label: C
options.text: To break down food into nutrients

options.label: D
options.text: To eliminate waste from the body

options.label: A
options.text: Cerebrum

options.label: B
options.text: Cerebellum

options.label: C
options.text: Autonomic nervous system

options.label: D
options.text: Brainstem

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It is exhaled out of the body

options.label: C
options.text: It is stored in the lungs

options.label: D
options.text: It is broken down into oxygen and nitrogen

options.text: 30-40 times

options.label: D
options.text: 50-60 times

options.label: B
options.text: Photosynthesis

options.label: C
options.text: Diffusion

options.label: D
options.text: Osmosis

options.label: A
options.text: To transport oxygen to the body's cells

options.label: B
options.text: To break down food into nutrients

options.label: C
options.text: To eliminate waste from the body

options.label: D
options.text: To regulate body temperature

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: 5,000 liters

options.label: C
options.text: 10,000 liters

options.label: D
options.text: 20,000 liters

options.label: A
options.text: To regulate body temperature

options.label: B
options.text: To break down food into nutrients

options.label: C
options.text: To control the body's vital functions, including breathing

options.label: D
options.text: To eliminate waste from the body

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: By releasing it into the bloodstream

options.label: C
options.text: By exhaling it out of the body

options.label: D
options.text: By breaking it down into oxygen and nitrogen

options.label: A
options.text: Alveoli

options.label: B
options.text: Bronchioles

options.label: C
options.text: Bronchi

options.label: D

options.text: To transport oxygen to the body's cells
